back up everything in /etc: actually you should really be backing up everything in /etc and /home on a regular basis, to save yourself frustrations later
/home contains per-user settings, /etc contains systemwide settings (in general).
so if you set up a samba share (file sharing with windows/other types of computers), the settings would go in /etc/samba
you can't go wrong backing up /etc, it's very tiny. Here's my backup list: /home, /etc, /usr/local/bin, /usr/local/sbin (the latter two are for scripts, you can skip them if you didn't write any)

This is the type of command I use: rsync -avz --progress --delete --numeric-ids /etc /backup/ . Notice that /etc has no trailing slash and /backup/ does. This is important.
with cp you could lose (overwrite) timestamps, which can be useful for tracking things down later.
for example, if I used cp to back up my music and had a crash, I'd never know which ones were the latest ones added.
